subject: AUDIO SERVICE HAS NOW CLOSED FOR THE WEEK. THE ASIA DESK WILL REOPEN ON SUNDAY AT 2200GMT, EUROPEAN SERVICE WILL RESUME ON MONDAY AT 0630GMT. HAVE A PLEASANT WEEKEND.
RANsquawk Central Bank Weekly Briefing 24 Aug 2018
content:
* JACKSON HOLE RECAP: FED CHAIR POWELL: The Fed Chair’s Jackson Hole address did not provide much of surprise, with his comments in line with Fed’s recent guidance. He restated that a gradual path of interest rate hikes remains appropriate if strong income and job growth continue and noted there are no signs of inflation accelerating above 2% both assertions contributed to an overall dovish market reaction. He then finally noted the US economy faces risks factors from both abroad and domestically – as alluded in the FOMC’s latest minutes – though there was no mention of trade risks and Fed’s independence in the text of his speech. Analysts said that Powell’s view that inflation will not accelerate above 2% suggests that he will wait and see, when the Fed gets to the neutral rate, rather than continue to tighten rates.  FED'S MESTER (VOTER, HAWK) said Q3 has come in strong, and she does not see signs of overheating, and therefore thinks gradual hikes seems appropriate. She sees the neutral rate around 3.0%. She also noted the Fed is monitoring financial conditions carefully and that fiscal policy could provide upside to the Fed's forecasts. In terms of downsides risks, she said the Fed is monitoring the tariff situation, noting there are some risks but not excesses. She did mention that firms in her district have expressed concerns over tariffs, but have not seen the impact in the data yet. FED'S BULLARD (NON-VOTER, DOVE) once again warned the Fed to remain cautious about action that inverts the yield curve as the market outlook points towards flattening action. He stated that personally he would not raise rates for the rest of the year as he does not see much inflation pressure in the US and as he believes markets are more dovish than the Fed.  Bullard argued that 2018 will be a good year for growth supported by the fiscal stimulus and other factors, though a slowdown should be expected in 2019 and 2020. His long-term growth forecast is ~2%, though showing signs of flexibility by mentioning that if growth comes in stronger than expected, policy can be adjusted. On the labour market, he thinks the current level of wage gains are not 'out of line' and low unemployment is not a threat. Finally, he believes if Japan and Europe start tightening, it would be good news. FED'S KAPLAN (NON-VOTER, DOVISH) reiterated comments made on Thursday that the Fed should move rates towards neutral, emphasizing gradual rate and expecting 3-4 rate hikes in the next 9-12 months. He then went on to note that cyclical effects are pushing prices upwards and that he anticipates core inflation rising to 2% by the end of this year. He is encouraged by the current growth pace, but he is worried about the outlook of 2020 when the impact of fiscal stimulus recedes noting stimulus tailwind could turn into headwind ahead. On the oil market, he noted oil prices are vulnerable to the upside citing risks over Iran and Venezuela and sees the market moving into a position of undersupply in 3-5 years. Finally, citing businesses, he said tariffs are having a negative impact on spending plans.

* FOMC MINUTES: The minutes of the FOMC’s July/August meeting were interpreted as slightly dovish after the central bank warned that escalation of trade disputes was a potentially consequential downside risk to the economy, with all participants suggesting that ongoing trade disagreements and proposed trade measures were an important source of uncertainty; any large-scale and prolonged trade dispute would likely have an adverse impact on business sentiment, investment and employment. The Fed also saw growth slowing in the second half of the year. While the headlines gave the impression that the Fed is becoming increasingly concerned by the said risks (and the immediate market reaction leaned dovish, albeit the reaction was short-lived), RBC's analysts argue that it may be misleading, noting that while the downside risks were mentioned, prior to that discussion, there was a discussion about the upside risks: "This is not a Fed that is all of a sudden worried only about downside risks. Indeed, the conversation about the downside was actually a discussion about risks in general—both upside and downside," RBC says, "moreover, most of the risks they mention are all extreme ideas — trade and EM in particular," and RBC suggests that the discussion of downside risks was likely stemming from a conversation on modelling economic shocks. RBC also notes that the 'risk' from trade is a price issue for the Fed: "the Fed's first inclination in the context of rising prices would be to raise rates more aggressively (not that we think that should be a baseline view at this point). Ultimately, for all of the spin on risks, it seemed to be lost in the headlines that the Fed also intimated in the Minutes that they are going to raise rates in September. How's that for the weight they are placing on those downside risks?" After the release of the minutes, money markets continued to price the chances of two additional hikes in 2018 (in line with the dots) at around 65%, little changed.

* ECB: The minutes of the central bank's latest meeting provided few surprises. The central bank said that the threat of protectionism and prominent trade tensions could weigh on confidence in the Euro-area, but sounded upbeat on the economy, arguing that expectations remain that the H1 2018 slowdown was temporary, growth was broad-based and solid, and in-line with the June projections; on price pressures, it said that uncertainties around inflation were receding. Policymakers were unanimous in maintaining policy stance, and were satisfied that the June decisions are well-understood by markets. Finally, it said that winding down of its asset purchases will be subject to incoming data.

* ECB SUCCESSION: A report in German media this week suggests that Germany is considering putting forward a candidate for the upcoming EU Commission Presidency, following the EU Parliamentary elections in May 2019. Analysts note that this would entail not nominating hawk Jens Weidmann for the ECB's top job. There have been lingering doubts that Weidmann would garner enough support to gain the job, and analysts argue that Germany pursuing the EU top position would reinforce this view.

* RIKSBANK: Ahead of the Riksbank's 6 September Monetary Policy Report meeting, analysts at SEB are expecting the central bank to lower its repo rates forecasts by 10bps; but despite this lowering the probability for a rate rise in Q4, SEB still expects the Riksbank to continue to signal that a hike this year is the main scenario. "Despite CPIF above target we think that the board majority (including Ingves casting vote) will highlight that CPIF ex energy has surprised on the downside again and that this increases the risk that inflation will fall below target when the impact from higher energy prices subsides in the beginning of next year," SEB writes, "a continued downward trend for service inflation, which in July declined to a level only marginally higher than in 2014-2015, further emphasises this risk." The central bank will likely take the weakening SEK into account, since most of the Board will want to avoid a sharp depreciation that might follow (as it did at the April meeting). "Also stronger than expected GDP growth is a slight upside risk to the repo rate forecast, but the board will most likely continue to puta very low weight on growth," SEB adds.

* NORGES BANK SURVEY: The central bank's Q3 expectations survey showed inflation slightly higher, as well as firming expectations of wage growth (Seen at 2.8% vs the NB's forecast for 2.9%; 2019 seen at 3.0% vs NB's 3.3%; 5-years ahead was at 3.1% vs the NB's 3.8% estimate). This was the second survey that captures the lowering of the inflation target, and SEB's analysts argue that "Although CPI expectations moved marginally higher, long-term inflation expectations remain close to 2.5%. In the June MPR, the central bank assumed that it will take some time for inflation expectations to adjust to the new target," and hence, SEB believes that the Norges Bank will see inflation expectations as remaining anchored. Looking ahead, SEB says that the central bank is remains optimistic relative to the survey. "The bank has revised its estimate for annual wages higher in line with the upward adjustment of the output gap. Absent surprises in capacity utilisation, we do not expect the Norges Bank to make larger revisions to its projection on the back of this survey."

* RBA MINUTES: The latest edition of the central bank's meeting minutes had little by way of new information; the central bank did note that while the direct impact of trade wars was likely to be small, it did pose risks to investment and confidence. The broad message from the minutes was that there is no urgency for the central bank to tweak policy in the near-term, though the next rate move was more likely to be a rate rise, rather than a rate cut. After the minutes, analysts at Westpac updated their RBA rate forecasts, and now sees the cash rate staying on hold through 2018, 2019 and 2020. "Factors which we consider important in this profile are: a steady weakening in the housing market through 2018 and 2019, low inflation, benign wages growth, and clear signs of a slowdown in the world economy," Westpac writes, adding that the Minutes mention most of these factors "but appear to be overly hopeful that economic activity and income growth will be sufficient to justify a rate hike at some point."

* RBNZ: On the side lines of Jackson Hole, RBNZ Governor Orr said that the Reserve Bank is not in any hurry to lift rates, and at the same time, Orr did not rule out a cut as the next policy move. On the currency, Orr said he was “very pleased” with how it has been trading.

* SARB: Rising inflation dynamics may prompt intervention from the South African Reserve Bank, Barclays analysts say. The July CPI data breached the psychological 5% YY level to the upside, and Barclays says is on track to rise to 6.2% YY by March 2019. "Details of the reading suggest that although core CPI also climbed marginally higher to 4.3% YY, demand pull inflation remains relatively weak. The key issue from here is the outlook on the currency and associated pass-through in the period ahead." Barclays argues that owing to the significant downside surprise in the penultimate CPI data, all things being equal, a sustained breach of USDZAR 14.55 might trigger SARB action since this sort of a move could jeopardise the attainment of the 3%-6% inflation target in 2019. However, while that is a risk, Barclays says it is not its baseline view, and sees policy on hold for now. "Inflation is likely to fall back to 5.8% YY in April 2019, and to close 2019 around 5.7% YY, allowing policymakers to stay put for now. The fact that high-frequency activity data that has been published over the past fortnight or so continue to point towards a possibly weaker GDP growth outcome than our already below-consensus forecast of 1.3% leads us to believe that the SARB may be more tolerant of a short-term target breach and chose to focus even more on second-round effects." Barclays concludes that, as things currently stand, "while there is hardly evidence of unravelling second-round inflation, we note that this could change as the currency trades weaker."

* CBR: The Russian central bank this week made the decision to halt its FX purchases until the end of September after the rouble's recent slide, and driving the decision was the notion that the CBR wants to "increase the predictability of the actions of the monetary authorities and reduce volatility in the financial markets." UBS says the move was tactical move to reassure the markets that the CBR is keeping a close eye on financial stability, but argues that the root of RUB pressure lies elsewhere: "We don’t expect the CBR to try and proactively influence the level of the exchange rate via interventions. Beyond the positive sentiment impact, a seven-week pause in purchases (including earlier August suspension) should leave c. $8.3bln buffer for the current account inflows to absorb higher demand for FX from residents and non-residents alike," UBS says, adding that "a sharp decline in RUBUSD basis swap to levels last seen in early 2016 points to a domestic shortage of FX liquidity. We think this at least partly explains why this time the FX market was more sensitive to the return of the CBR than in April – and why the CBR decided to postpone purchases for a longer period."

* MNB: The Hungarian Central Bank stood pat on rates at the 21st August meeting, as expected, keeping the base rate at 0.9%. The Monetary Council believes growth in the Hungarian economy will pick up further in 2018, adding that “the inflation target is still expected to be achieved in a sustainable manner from mid-2019” while citing the temporary inflation-boosting effects are due to the rise oil prices. The central bank noted inflation developments were in-line with expectations. Regarding wage growth, MNB said “inflationary pressures from wages continue to be moderate”, consistent with expectations, while also taking account the ECB’s underlying inflation projection of continued moderation in the euro area in the coming years. In terms of how the market digested the decision, initially there was little move in the HUF, however the currency strengthened in a delayed reaction.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - US MARKET WRAP - 24th Aug 2018: Powell Jackson Hole comments judged slightly dovish, S&P closes at fresh record high
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down/flat, crude up, dollar down.
  • REAR-VIEW: Fed's Chair Powell dovish at Jackson Hole; US Durable Goods soft; Baker Hughes rig count; Trump to impose sanctions on Venezuela & US sanctions on Russia to remain in place; China threatens continue US retaliation.
  • NEXT WEEK: US Trade , GDP (2nd Reading), Pending Home Sales, PCE; Canadian GDP; Japan Labour Market; China PMI.

* FED CHAIR POWELL: The Fed Chair’s Jackson Hole address did not provide much of surprise, with his comments in line with Fed’s recent guidance. He restated that a gradual path of interest rate hikes remains appropriate if strong income and job growth continue and noted there are no signs of inflation accelerating above 2% both assertions contributed to an overall dovish market reaction. He then finally noted the US economy faces risks factors from both abroad and domestically – as alluded in the FOMC’s latest minutes – though there was no mention of trade risks and Fed’s independence in the text of his speech. Analysts said that Powell’s view that inflation will not accelerate above 2% suggests that he will wait and see, when the Fed gets to the neutral rate, rather than continue to tighten rates.  

* FED'S MESTER (VOTER, HAWK) said Q3 has come in strong, and she does not see signs of overheating, and therefore thinks gradual hikes seems appropriate. She sees the neutral rate around 3.0%. She also noted the Fed is monitoring financial conditions carefully and that fiscal policy could provide upside to the Fed's forecasts. In terms of downsides risks, she said the Fed is monitoring the tariff situation, noting there are some risks but not excesses. She did mention that firms in her district have expressed concerns over tariffs, but have not seen the impact in the data yet.

* FED'S BULLARD (NON-VOTER, DOVE) once again warned the Fed to remain cautious about action that inverts the yield curve as the market outlook points towards flattening action. He stated that personally he would not raise rates for the rest of the year as he does not see much inflation pressure in the US and as he believes markets are more dovish than the Fed.  Bullard argued that 2018 will be a good year for growth supported by the fiscal stimulus and other factors, though a slowdown should be expected in 2019 and 2020. His long-term growth forecast is ~2%, though showing signs of flexibility by mentioning that if growth comes in stronger than expected, policy can be adjusted. On the labour market, he thinks the current level of wage gains are not 'out of line' and low unemployment is not a threat. Finally, he believes if Japan and Europe start tightening, it would be good news.

* FED'S KAPLAN (NON-VOTER, DOVISH) reiterated comments made on Thursday that the Fed should move rates towards neutral, emphasizing gradual rate and expecting 3-4 rate hikes in the next 9-12 months. He then went on to note that cyclical effects are pushing prices upwards and that he anticipates core inflation rising to 2% by the end of this year. He is encouraged by the current growth pace, but he is worried about the outlook of 2020 when the impact of fiscal stimulus recedes noting stimulus tailwind could turn into headwind ahead. On the oil market, he noted oil prices are vulnerable to the upside citing risks over Iran and Venezuela and sees the market moving into a position of undersupply in 3-5 years. Finally, citing businesses, he said tariffs are having a negative impact on spending plans.

* CHINA TRADE TALKS: The Chinese Foreign Ministry said they will keep retaliating if the US keeps imposing "unreasonable" trade measures.

* NAFTA: Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo said they are very far down the list of issues that concern us in NAFTA talks.

Also on August 23rd Inside Trade reported that the US and Mexico have reached an agreement over auto tariffs that were not meeting the requirements from NAFTA’s rules of origin, a major sticking points in the negotiation process. As a side note, in the last two months US and Mexico have been negotiating bilaterally to solve sticking points; once those are finalised Canada will be able to re-join negotiations.

* GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump's Adviser Bolton said US sanctions against Russia will remain in place until it changes its behaviour. On the Russian side, Deputy Foreign Minister said Moscow recognises attempts made by the US to revise potential agreements reached at the Tump-Putin summit, adding there are no signs yet that US is ready to normalise relations. On the US side, US President Trump's Adviser Bolton said US sanctions against Russia are to remain in place until Russia changes its behaviour. Elsewhere, administration officials reported that Trump is considering more sanctions on Venezuela targeting the region’s oil production.

* US DURABLES posted the largest decline in six months,  falling by 1.7% against an expected drop of 0.5%. The weakness in the data was mostly driven by the volatile aircraft component, which fell sharply, whilst other categories, including ore orders, posted decent gains. Analysts at Oxford Economics note that ‘underlying momentum remains strong’ as core orders and core shipments remain solid and should push GDP to 3.1% in Q3.

* STOCKS: Autodesk Inc (ADSK) was one of the day’s biggest gainers following its Q2 earnings where it beat expectations on the top and bottom lines. On the flip side, Foot Locker Inc (FL) edged lower; although earnings beat expectations, SSS missed coming in at +0.5% vs Exp. +0.7%; other retailers also lagged behind with names like Gap (GPS), Macy’s (M) and Kroger (KR) all down on the day. Netflix (NFLX) surged more than 4% after an upgrade at Suntrust and similarly Mylan (MYL) posted gains following an upgrade Evercore. Philip Morris (PM) however dipped lower on a downgrade at Jefferies. Papa John’s (PZZA) spiked higher following reports it had attained Bank of America (BAC) and Lazard (LAZ) as financial advisors. In M&A Enbridge (ENB) announced it is to acquire all of Spectra Energy Partners’ (SEP) public equity for USD 3.3bln transaction. Elsewhere, China Biologic (CBPO) dropped significantly when CITIC Capital MB Investment Limited withdrew its preliminary acquisition proposal.

* WTI (V8) SETTLES 89 CENTS HIGHER AT USD 68.72/BBL; BRENT (V8) SETTLES $1.09 HIGHER AT $75.82/BBL. Traders were citing technical factors for Friday’s crude action where prices of Brent scaled a four-week high (while WTI prints the first weekly advance in four weeks). Citi notes it has been quote a technical accomplishment that now means last month’s crude performance is a base where they expect prices will use to launch to perhaps as high as $80 for Brent. The slide in the buck was also supporting crude. From a fundamental perspective, the upcoming sanctions on Iran’s oil sector have this week been cited as the chief driver of crude prices (the sanctions on crude will kick in on 4 November). In other news, China’s Unipec will resume US crude purchases in October following a two-month hiatus, PVM reported; and a report out of Norway suggests the SWF will remain invested in O&G shares. Baker Hughes oil rigs were down 9 at 860, with US drillers cutting most oil rigs since May 2016 , gas rigs down 4 at 182 and total rigs -13 to 1044.

* US 10-YEAR T-NOTES SETTLED 2+ TICK LOWER AT 120-16+: There was decent volume in the Treasury complex, as Jackson Hole got underway. Powell’s comments were judged to be on the dovish side, which helped 10s catch a bid; Informa reported that traders priced in a pause after two more hikes, and then the real money bid came back forcing poorly placed shorts to cover. Unsurprisingly, curves continued to flatten with 2s10s and 2s30s finding their customary cyclical narrows.

* DXY: A largely mundane Monday session and typically lethargic summer trade came to an abrupt halt as US President Trump took aim at the Fed again, and expressly mentioned chair Powell in his latest tweet bemoaning policy normalisation and the knock-on impact on the USD that has also strengthened due to Chinese and EU currency manipulation. The Dollar and index duly dumped and extended losses on Tuesday, before latest FOMC minutes maintained guidance for a September rate hike and did not remove a further 25bps tightening by year end even though global trade disputes pose a downside risk to central forecasts. The DXY started the week around 96.125 and reached 96.405 pre-Trump, then recoiled to just under 95.000 vs circa 95.300 awaiting Powell’s keynote speech from Jackson Hole, and drifted back towards 95.000 as he sees no evidence of inflation rising above 2%.

* AUD: Not quite zero to hero, but a marked turnaround in fortunes for the AUD that decoupled from closely tracking broad risk sentiment and Yuan moves (in response to PBoC fixings and US-China tariff developments) to Aussie politics watch. AUDUSD hit peaks of around 0.7380 and lows of 0.7235 after PM Turnbull only just survived a no confidence vote, but failed to overcome the subsequent leadership challenge as his opponents within the Liberal Party seized upon the opportunity to oust him. However, the new PM designate and soon to be former Treasurer Morrison has been given the thumbs up, this far, with AUDUSD firmly back above 0.7300 and approaching 0.7350 having cleared heavy option expiry interest at 0.7305 (1.4 bn).

* EUR, NZD: Ending a choppy week as the next best G10 performers, and with the single currency close to fresh highs vs the Greenback above 1.1600 (a close over the 55 DMA at 1.1617 would be technically bullish), while the Kiwi is retesting offers ahead of 0.6700 vs nearly 0.6600 at the extreme having only derived fleeting support from much stronger than expected NZ retail sales date earlier in the week. Note, RBNZ Governor Orr stuck to a largely open stance on the next policy move, while ECB minutes did not offer much new, but Weidmann was his usual more hawkish self.

* GBP, CAD: Also benefiting from the generally softer USD with Cable considerably nearer the top of its 1.2936-1.2727 range, albeit challenging key technical support again vs the Eur (0.9030-35) after no further progress or sign of a resolution to the may Brexit sticking points between the UK and EU. Meanwhile, a degree of NAFTA disappointment nullified high/rising BoC rate hike expectations (September probability not far off 50%) to leave the Loonie relatively midway between 1.3100-1.2980 trading parameters as Thursday’s ‘deadline’ for a handshake agreement between the US and Mexico came and went with no deal made even in principle and negotiations roll over to another week (and end of August now looking more in doubt as a result).

* JPY: The major laggard and underperformer as overall risk aversion gradually turned to increased appetite, or improved at least, while softer than forecast Japanese inflation data also impacted. USDJPY off near 111.50 peaks, but firmly above 111.00 having been as low as 109.75 at one stage.

* EM: More sharp swings on all the well documented and ongoing negative factors, but some redemption and intervention prompted a short squeeze and recovery in the Rand and Rouble with positive contagion spreading across the region, albeit to varying degrees. The key events - US President Trump raising eyebrows at SA constitutional changes on land appropriation, but ZAR rebounding post strong inflation data and pledges to protect the Rand and prevent financial instability. Similar platitudes from Russia amidst heightened tensions with the US and ahead of sanctions from the White House taking effect from Monday, but it was the CBR decision to stop building reserves until the end of September due to sufficient tools to defend the Rub that actually appeared to stop the rot. USDZAR around 14.2700, USDRUB 67.5000, USDTRY circa 6.0300, USDMXN 18.8150 and USDBRL 4.0800.

* NEXT WEEK: Monday: UK Market Holiday, German Ifo Survey. Tuesday: US Trade Balance. Wednesday: French GDP, US GDP (2nd Reading), US Pending Home Sales. Thursday: German Labour Market, German CPI (Prelim), US PCE, Canadian GDP (Quarterly). Friday: Japan Labour Market, Tokyo CPI, China PMI, EZ CPI (Prelim). Click here for RANsquawk’s full week-ahead preview.

Meanwhile, a degree of NAFTA disappointment nullified high/rising BoC rate hike expectations (September probability not far off 50%) to leave the Loonie relatively midway between 1.3100-1.2980 trading parameters as Thursday’s ‘deadline’ for a handshake agreement between the US and Mexico came and went with no deal made even in principle and negotiations roll over to another week (and end of August now looking more in doubt as a result).

JPY

The major laggard and underperformer as overall risk aversion gradually turned to increased appetite, or improved at least, while softer than forecast Japanese inflation data also impacted. Usd/Jpy off near 111.50 peaks, but firmly above 111.00 having been as low as 109.75 at one stage.

EM

More sharp swings on all the well documented and ongoing negative factors, but some redemption and intervention prompted a short squeeze and recovery in the Rand and Rouble with positive contagion spreading across the region, albeit to varying degrees. The key events - US President Trump raising eyebrows at SA constitutional changes on land appropriation, but Zar rebounding post strong inflation data and pledges to protect the Rand and prevent financial instability. Similar platitudes from Russia amidst heightened tensions with the US and ahead of sanctions from the White House taking effect from Monday, but it was the CBR decision to stop building reserves until the end of September due to sufficient tools to defend the Rub that actually appeared to stop the rot. Usd/Zar around 14.2700, Usd/Rub 67.5000, Usd/Try circa 6.0300, Usd/Mxn 18.8150 and Usd/Brl 4.0800.

content:

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Tentative trade ahead of Fed Chair Powell’s speech at Jackson Hole
  • AUD the biggest G10 mover overnight as Morrison sworn in as new Prime Minster
  • Looking ahead, highlight include, US durable goods and Fed’s Chair Powell to speak at the Jackson Hole Symposium

ASIA 
Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested the weak lead from Wall St, a lack of progress during US-China trade discussions and change of leadership in Australia. ASX 200 (+0.1%) traded choppy amid the tumultuous political climate, although sentiment later improved after Treasurer Morrison beat former Home Affairs Minister Dutton to become the PM. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was underpinned by a weaker JPY, while Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were initially the worst performers following the stalemate at US-China trade talks and with the biggest movers amongst Hong Kong’s large caps also dictated by earnings, but the Shanghai Comp. reversed course close to end of trade, and ended the day up. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with demand subdued amid strength in Tokyo stocks, although downside was also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 950bln in 1yr-10yr JGBs and following softer than expected CPI data. 
PBoC refrained from reverse repos but later injected CNY 149bln through 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8710 (Prev. 6.8367) 
White House official said trade talks between US and China have concluded and that discussions included structural issues related to China and how to achieve trade fairness, while China Mofcom stated that US and China had constructive and candid exchange regarding trade and will keep in touch on next steps. However, there were earlier reports that US-China trade talks didn't provide any visible sign of progress which reduces prospects of an agreement soon, according to sources which added that China seemed unready to offer new solutions to US concerns related to trade deficit and coerced transfer of tech. (Newswires/WSJ) 
Chinese Foreign Ministry says they will keep retaliating if US keeps imposing "unreasonable" trade measures. (Newswires) 
Japanese National CPI (Jul) 0.9% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Jul) 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 0.8%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Jul) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%) 
Australian Treasurer Morrison won the party vote to become Liberal Party leader and the next Australian PM via 45 vs. 40 votes. This was after outgoing PM Turnbull was forced to hold a party meeting and leadership vote which was contended by Morrison, Foreign Minister Bishop and Peter Dutton. (Newswires) 
EU/UK/US 
UK Chancellor Hammond has warned of "large fiscal consequences" if the UK leaves the EU with no-deal, stating that UK GDP could take a hit of up to 10.3%. (Sky News) 
US President Trump is said to have offered Italy help with buying government bonds. (Newswires) 
Italy’s Deputy PM and Five-Star leader Di Maio stated his party will vote to suspend EU funding next year if the European Commission does not get a deal for other states to take in some of migrants on an Italian coastguard ship today. (Newswires) 
Riksbank's Jochnick says rate path shows probability for an October hike, and wants to see broader inflation in the economy; adding the recent weak crown should have an effect on inflation further ahead. (Newswires) 
German GDP Detailed YY SA (Q2) 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.0%) 
German GDP Detailed QQ SA Q2 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%) 
German GDP Detailed YY NSA Q2 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.3%) 
US President Trump is considering more sanctions on Venezuela, as according to senior administration officials. (McClatchy) 
Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said he sees 3-4 hikes in the next 9-12 months and stated he is comfortable with 4 hikes this year, while he also commented that officials will ignore political pressure or attacks and that he hopes Fed can get to the neutral rate without seeing a yield curve inversion. (Newswires) 
Mexico Foreign Minister Videgaray said NAFTA discussions in Washington will continue 0930EDT today. In related news, Canadian PM Trudeau said they are encouraged by NAFTA progress and that they hope for a win-win-win NAFTA deal, while there were also comments from Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland that Canada would need to 'agree to any final conclusion' achieved on rules of origin in NAFTA talks between the US and Mexico. (Newswires) 

 Manhattan DA is said to be considering charges against 2 Trump Organization officials. (NYT) 
EQUITIES 
European equites have started the flat, with the FTSE MIB the outperforming bourse. This is being driven by banking names, and comes as a result of reports suggesting Unicredit (+0.7%) have hired Rothschild for a deal with SocGen (+1.2%). The gains in banking names are broad based, with the sector outperforming (Stoxx Europe 600 Banking Index +0.4%) and co.’s in the sector leading bourses such as: 
• CAC (SocGen +1.2% & BNP Paribas +1.0%) • FTSE MIB (Unicredit +0.7%)  • DAX (Commerzbank +0.9%) • SMI (UBS +1.5%, Credit Suisse +0.9%) 
 
Shire (+2.4%) are leading the gains in the FTSE 100 as they received approval for a ground-breaking hereditary angioedema treatment.  
FIXED INCOME 
Fundamental drivers remain few and far between, but Bunds and Gilts have emerged from initial and early bouts of selling pressure to trade above parity at fresh Eurex and Liffe intraday highs of 163.16 and 123.41 (+10 and +11 ticks vs -10 an -7 ticks at one stage). So, ranges are still relatively restrained and volumes seasonally light, but divergence from the core to periphery and US Treasuries a bit more apparent as the clock ticks down to JH. Conversely, Italian BTPs are back under pressure on latest comments from Government officials stressing that the EC’s fiscal mandate will be challenged and withholding budget contributions used a bargaining tool, following not much buck for US President Trump’s offer to buy Italian bonds. Back to USTs, futures are nudging marginal new overnight lows with the curve fractionally steeper before the start of Fed speakers and durable goods data. 
FX 
AUD - Some calm after the political storm, and a positive market response (so far) to the prospect of former Treasurer Morrison taking over from Turnbull as leader of the Liberal Party and PM. Indeed, Aud/Usd has bounced firmly from circa 0.7235-40 lows to around 0.7290 and eyeing hefty option expiry interest just above at 0.7305 (1.4 bn), while the Aud/NZD cross is back up near 1.0950 having only just held above 1.0900 amidst the unfolding drama overnight. However, the Kiwi has also caught a bid on the more stable situation down under to retest 0.6650 vs its US peer. 
SEK - Another major outperformer and gainer, but largely due to Riksbank commentary via Af Jochnick noting inflation rising and nearing target, above forecast Q2 growth and the rate path indicating an October hike. She also acknowledged that recent Krona weakness should underpin price pressures ahead, and on the note Swedish PPI data for July picked up pace from the previous month. Eur/Sek down to 10.5260 from 10.5815 at one stage, with 10.5000 the obvious objective. 
EUR/GBP - Also firmer vs the Greenback, but within recent ranges as the DXY pivots around 95.500 awaiting Fed chair Powell and a raft of other FOMC members all attending the Jackson Hole Symposium.  However, the single currency remains capped ahead of 1.1600 and within proximity of decent expiries from 1.1545-55 (1.2 bn), while Cable is back within 1.2800-50 parameters amidst no Brexit progress on the 20% outstanding and make or break sticking points between the UK and EU. Hence, the Eur/Gbp cross remains above 0.9000, albeit not breaching major technical resistance in the 0.9030-35 area. 
CAD - Holding pretty flat vs its US rival in a 1.3100-1.3075 range with firmer crude prices providing the Loonie with some traction after yesterday’s NAFTA handshake deadline (albeit for the US and Mexico not Canada) passed without fanfare and talks are now extending into next week, at least. Ahead, BoC Governor Poloz appears from Jackson Hole on Saturday. 
CHF/JPY - Narrowly mixed vs the Dollar as the Franc claws back some lost ground to rotate around 0.9850, but Usd/Jpy extends its range break through 111.00 towards 111.50 in wake of softer than expected Japanese inflation data overnight. 
EM - The Rub and Zar continue to rebound and are on course to end a turbulent week in better shape than other regional currencies (such as the Try and Brl) still suffering from multiple bearish/negative factors, like sanctions, diplomatic tensions, tariffs, on top of domestic political, economic and fiscal issues. Meanwhile, after no material progress in US-China trade talks, the Yuan is back on the wane and the PBoC has resumed its rising mid-point fixing trend. 
COMMODITIES 
The oil market is in the green, with both WTI and Brent up ~1.0% and extending gains above USD 68.00/BBL and USD 75.00/BBL respectively. This comes amid reports of continued strike action at Total’s (FP FP) North Sea oil and gas fields alongside a softer USD.  

 In the metals scope gold is benefitting from a softer USD and is up 0.4% on the day, with the yellow metal set for a 0.3% gain for the week. Copper has pared early losses and is set for its first positive session in three, alongside the best week in four, as the construction material has shed-off trade concerns. Steel prices have seen a recovery (0.5%) as a fall in Chinese steel stocks has been noted, but is still set for it’s worst week in eight (-1.2%).

EQUITIES

European equites have started flat, with the FTSE MIB the outperforming bourse. This is being driven by banking names, and comes as a result of reports suggesting Unicredit (+0.7%) have hired Rothschild for a deal with SocGen (+1.2%). The gains in banking names are broad based, with the sector outperforming (Stoxx Europe 600 Banking Index +0.4%) and co.’s in the sector leading bourses such as:

CAC (SocGen +1.2% & BNP Paribas +1.0%)

FTSE MIB (Unicredit +0.7%)

DAX (Commerzbank +0.9%)

SMI (UBS +1.5%, Credit Suisse +0.9%)

Shire (+2.4%) are leading the gains in the FTSE 100 as they received approval for a ground-breaking hereditary angioedema treatment.

FX

AUD - Some calm after the political storm, and a positive market response (so far) to the prospect of former Treasurer Morrison taking over from Turnbull as leader of the Liberal Party and PM. Indeed, Aud/Usd has bounced firmly from circa 0.7235-40 lows to around 0.7290 and eyeing hefty option expiry interest just above at 0.7305 (1.4 bn), while the Aud/NZD cross is back up near 1.0950 having only just held above 1.0900 amidst the unfolding drama overnight. However, the Kiwi has also caught a bid on the more stable situation down under to retest 0.6650 vs its US peer.

SEK - Another major outperformer and gainer, but largely due to Riksbank commentary via Af Jochnick noting inflation rising and nearing target, above forecast Q2 growth and the rate path indicating an October hike. She also acknowledged that recent Krona weakness should underpin price pressures ahead, and on the note Swedish PPI data for July picked up pace from the previous month. Eur/Sek down to 10.5260 from 10.5815 at one stage, with 10.5000 the obvious objective.

EUR/GBP - Also firmer vs the Greenback, but within recent ranges as the DXY pivots around 95.500 awaiting Fed chair Powell and a raft of other FOMC members all attending the Jackson Hole Symposium.  However, the single currency remains capped ahead of 1.1600 and within proximity of decent expiries from 1.1545-55 (1.2 bn), while Cable is back within 1.2800-50 parameters amidst no Brexit progress on the 20% outstanding and make or break sticking points between the UK and EU. Hence, the Eur/Gbp cross remains above 0.9000, albeit not breaching major technical resistance in the 0.9030-35 area.

CAD - Holding pretty flat vs its US rival in a 1.3100-1.3075 range with firmer crude prices providing the Loonie with some traction after yesterday’s NAFTA handshake deadline (albeit for the US and Mexico not Canada) passed without fanfare and talks are now extending into next week, at least. Ahead, BoC Governor Poloz appears from Jackson Hole on Saturday.

CHF/JPY - Narrowly mixed vs the Dollar as the Franc claws back some lost ground to rotate around 0.9850, but Usd/Jpy extends its range break through 111.00 towards 111.50 in wake of softer than expected Japanese inflation data overnight.

EM - The Rub and Zar continue to rebound and are on course to end a turbulent week in better shape than other regional currencies (such as the Try and Brl) still suffering from multiple bearish/negative factors, like sanctions, diplomatic tensions, tariffs, on top of domestic political, economic and fiscal issues. Meanwhile, after no material progress in US-China trade talks, the Yuan is back on the wane and the PBoC has resumed its rising mid-point fixing trend.

FIXED INCOME

Fundamental drivers remain few and far between, but Bunds and Gilts have emerged from initial and early bouts of selling pressure to trade above parity at fresh Eurex and Liffe intraday highs of 163.16 and 123.41 (+10 and +11 ticks vs -10 an -7 ticks at one stage). So, ranges are still relatively restrained and volumes seasonally light, but divergence from the core to periphery and US Treasuries a bit more apparent as the clock ticks down to JH. Conversely, Italian BTPs are back under pressure on latest comments from Government officials stressing that the EC’s fiscal mandate will be challenged and withholding budget contributions used a bargaining tool, following not much buck for US President Trump’s offer to buy Italian bonds. Back to USTs, futures are nudging marginal new overnight lows with the curve fractionally steeper before the start of Fed speakers and durable goods data.

COMMODITIES

The oil market is in the green, with both WTI and Brent up ~1.0% and extending gains above USD 68.00/BBL and USD 75.00/BBL respectively. This comes amid reports of continued strike action at Total’s (FP FP) North Sea oil and gas fields alongside a softer USD.

China's Unipec is to start purchasing US crude after a 2-month stoppage following tariff policy changes, according to sources.

In the metals scope gold is benefitting from a softer USD and is up 0.4% on the day, with the yellow metal set for a 0.3% gain for the week. Copper has pared early losses and is set for its first positive session in three, alongside the best week in four, as the construction material has shed-off trade concerns. Steel prices have seen a recovery (0.5%) as a fall in Chinese steel stocks has been noted, but is still set for it’s worst week in eight (-1.2%).

subject: BofAML Weekly Flow Report: Equities see inflows, bonds see small outflows, precious metals see large outflows
content:
Talking Points

  • Flows on the beach: $2.6bn into equities, $0.5bn out of bonds, $1.2bn out of gold
  • BofAML Bull & Bear Indicator: up to 3.3 from 3.0 as late-summer sentiment slowly drifts from bearish toward neutral; trough positioning supports risk assets; peak profits and peak policy explain poor 2018 bond/commodity/equity returns outside US equities
  • Waves & riptides: gold = contrarian buy (biggest outflows since Dec'16); IG inflows reaccelerating (important as IG = bull market "glue"); EU equity capitulation visible but EM capitulation not visible; 2018 tsunami of tech inflows has ended
  • The old, deflationary, polarized US bull: US stock prices hit all-time highs yet broker commissions down from $80bn to $30bn since 2000; contrast with Japan (23%), Eurozone (30%), China (42%) from all-time highs; S&P500 leadership narrow with market cap of FAAMG ($4.1tn) now > market cap of smallest 283 members
  • Positive autumn shock #1: combo of US inflation peak (as wages, oil, breakevens, US housing, bond sensitives imply)…GT10 <2.5% + China stimulus goes big…upward revisions to EM & EU EPS; best trade = long EM & EU banks
  • #2: US buybacks accelerate & effectively becomes QE4…35% of US profits in '18 being spent on buybacks (peak was 38% in 2007); US stock market decoupling continues
  • Negative autumn shock #1: spread widening in EM broadens to EU high yield & US IG (canary-in-coal mine) as combo of Quantitative Tightening, peak profits & excess debt causes credit contagion; best trade = short HY bonds
  • #2: autumn of hardball politics (UK on BREXIT, Italy budget & EU, China on trade) hits global PMIs & EPS forecasts + Dem midterm sweep…lurch to populist redistribution (e.g. stock buyback regulation); best trade = short US tech

Asset Class Flows:

  • Equities: inflows $2.6bn ($9.2bn ETF inflows, $6.6bn mutual fund outflows)
  • Bonds: small outflows ($0.5bn)
  • Precious metals: biggest outflows since Dec'16 ($1.2bn)

Fixed Income Flows:

  • Small IG bond fund inflows ($0.6bn)
  • Small HY bond outflows ($0.7bn)
  • Biggest EM debt outflows in 8 weeks ($1.6bn)
  • Modest muni fund inflows ($0.3bn)
  • Modest Govt/Tsy inflows ($0.6bn)
  • Tiny TIPS outflows ($47m)
  • Bank loan fund inflows 25 of past 26 weeks ($0.2bn)

Equity Flows

  • US: modest inflows ($4.1bn)
  • Japan: small inflows ($0.2bn)
  • Europe: 24th straight week of outflows ($1.1bn)
  • EM: small outflows ($0.1bn)
  • By style: inflows to US large cap ($1.7bn), US small cap ($1.5bn), US growth ($0.7bn); outflows US value ($0.7bn)
  • By sector: inflows real estate ($0.7bn), healthcare ($0.6bn), utilities ($0.1bn), tech ($0.1bn); outflows materials ($29m), consumer ($0.1bn), financials ($0.2bn), energy ($0.5bn)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

24th August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested the weak lead from Wall St, a lack of progress during US-China trade discussions and change of leadership in Australia. ASX 200 (+0.4%) traded choppy amid the tumultuous political climate, although sentiment later improved after Treasurer Morrison beat former Home Affairs Minister Dutton to become the PM. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was underpinned by a weaker JPY, while Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were the worst performers following the stalemate at US-China trade talks and with the biggest movers amongst Hong Kong’s large caps also dictated by earnings. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with demand subdued amid strength in Tokyo stocks, although downside was also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 950bln in 1yr-10yr JGBs and following softer than expected CPI data.

FTSE

Shire (SHP LN) – The US FDA approved a never-before-seen drug to treat types I and II hereditary angioedema (HAE) called lanadelumab. (Newswires)

Reckitt Benckiser (RB/ LN) – Co. is said to have lost an appeal against GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) in Australia in relation to the Nurofen case. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Premier Oil (PMO LN) – Premier have said that they are in the process of selecting contractors to develop an oilfield north of the Falklands, alongside being on the “buyside” for further opportunities in the North Sea, an area where some of the largest energy groups in the world are divesting. (Newswires)

Vedanta (VED LN) – Co. chairman said the Co. is to invest USD 8bln in 3 years on growth project across units. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ANTOFAGASTA (ANTO LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

DAX

Fresenius (FRE GY) – Lawyer for the co. has said he has a “powerful case” vs. Akorn (AKRX) for merger violations in the failed USD 4.7bln agreement. Akorn (AKRX) shares fell 13% following these comments in US trade. (Newswires)

Munich Re (MUV2 GY) – Deal talks with Guggenheim are said to have been called off. Co. are said to have held talks with other companies to manage assets. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Japan has enlisted Airbus alongside Uber to develop flying car technology. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – The co. has reaffirmed their commitment to Russia after freezing ~USD5bln in assets yesterday to avoid sanction action. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Italy plans state lender Cassa Depositi e Prestiti (CDP) given a role in Geneo bridge rebuild with Atlantia. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

* SPX -0.17% at 2,856, NDX -0.14% at 7,413, DJIA -0.3% at 25,656.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: AMD (AMD) was higher after Rosenblatt raised the co.’s price target to a street high of $30 from $27. Walmart (WMT) was slightly lower after a UK competition watchdog started its formal investigation into the planned $7.3bln merger between the co.’s supermarket chain ASDA, and Sainsbury (SBRY LN). L Brands (LB) was under pressure on Thursday following poor earnings. LB slightly beat on both top & bottom lines, however, the co. lowered FY18 and Q3 EPS forecasts. Synopsys (SNPS) outperformed after both EPS & revenue were higher than expectations. Alibaba (BABA) was indecisive after its EPS beat but revenues fell, with the stock initially opening higher but giving up its gains as investors focused on the operating margin which fell 10% Q/Q and 35% y/y due to Ant Financial expenses, as well as the investment BABA is making in new areas.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 24th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed amid a weak lead from Wall St, a lack of progress during US-China trade discussions and a change of leadership in Australia
  • AUD was supported as Australian Treasurer Morrison becomes the new PMI
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German GDP, US durable goods and Fed’s Chair Powell to speak at the Jackson Hole Symposium

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested the weak lead from Wall St, a lack of progress during US-China trade discussions and change of leadership in Australia. ASX 200 (+0.4%) traded choppy amid the tumultuous political climate, although sentiment later improved after Treasurer Morrison beat former Home Affairs Minister Dutton to become the PM. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) was underpinned by a weaker JPY, while Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were the worst performers following the stalemate at US-China trade talks and with the biggest movers amongst Hong Kong’s large caps also dictated by earnings. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with demand subdued amid strength in Tokyo stocks, although downside was also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 950bln in 1yr-10yr JGBs and following softer than expected CPI data.

PBoC refrained from reverse repos but later injected CNY 149bln through 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8710 (Prev. 6.8367)

White House official said trade talks between US and China have concluded and that discussions included structural issues related to China and how to achieve trade fairness, while China Mofcom stated that US and China had constructive and candid exchange regarding trade and will keep in touch on next steps. However, there were earlier reports that US-China trade talks didn't provide any visible sign of progress which reduces prospects of an agreement soon, according to sources which added that China seemed unready to offer new solutions to US concerns related to trade deficit and coerced transfer of tech. (Newswires/WSJ)

Japanese National CPI (Jul) 0.9% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires)
Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Jul) 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 0.8%)
Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Jul) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%)


UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond has warned of "large fiscal consequences" if the UK leaves the EU with no-deal, stating that UK GDP could take a hit of up to 10.3%. (Sky News)

Italy’s Deputy PM and Five-Star leader Di Maio stated his party will vote to suspend EU funding next year if the European Commission does not get a deal for other states to take in some of migrants on an Italian coastguard ship today. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, price action was mostly quiet overnight as the greenback held on to recent gains against its major counterparts, which kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD near the prior day’s lows with the latter testing 1.2800 to the downside. AUD was initially subdued by the US-China stalemate and leadership uncertainty in Australia but was later supported by news of Treasurer Morrison’s win who was seen to be the more politically-stable option. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was higher on broad strength in the greenback, while MXN and CAD languished after Thursday passed without the announcement of the previously-speculated NAFTA handshake agreement.

Australian Treasurer Morrison won the party vote to become Liberal Party leader and the next Australian PM via 45 vs. 40 votes. This was after outgoing PM Turnbull was forced to hold a party meeting and leadership vote which was contended by Morrison, Foreign Minister Bishop and Peter Dutton. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities saw mild gains overnight in which WTI crude futures broke back above USD 68.00/bbl and Brent reclaimed the USD 75.00/bbl level amid reports of a continuation in North Sea oil strikes. Gold prices were marginally higher as the precious metal attempted to nurse its recent USD-induced losses, while copper also continued its rebound inline with the marginal upside seen across the complex.

North Sea Oil strikes are reportedly to continue as talks with Total have broken down. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo announced he will be making a 4th visit to North Korea and is reportedly planning the visit on August 27th. (Newswires)


US

The US Treasury sold $14bln of 5-year TIPS, which sold at the highest yield since 2009, stopping through by 0.1bps. On Thursday, the curve was mixed, though once again, there were new cyclical flats for the 2s5s and 2s10s, as has become almost customary on a daily basis. US 10-Year T-notes settled 1 tick lower at 120-19.

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dove) said the FOMC has spent some time discussing the yield curve and that outlook is for above trend expansion in the coming quarters, while he also noted trade uncertainty as the chief downside risk. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said the job of the Fed is to make decisions independent of politics and that impact of trade dispute on the US economy is so far modest but could affect business sentiment. Furthermore, Kaplan sees 3-4 hikes in the next 9-12 months and stated he is comfortable with 4 hikes this year, while he also commented that officials will ignore political pressure or attacks and that he hopes Fed can get to the neutral rate without seeing a yield curve inversion. (Newswires)

Mexico Economy Minister Guajardo said Mexican NAFTA negotiators are prepared to stay in Washington over the weekend if needed and later added they will have to work on NAFTA into next week, while Mexico Foreign Minister Videgaray said NAFTA discussions in Washington will continue 0930EDT today. In related news, Canadian PM Trudeau said they are encouraged by NAFTA progress and that they hope for a win-win-win NAFTA deal, while there were also comments from Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland that Canada would need to 'agree to any final conclusion' achieved on rules of origin in NAFTA talks between the US and Mexico. (Newswires)

US President Trump sought advice on the possibility of a Manafort pardon, although Trump lawyer Giuliani advised him against pardoning Manafort. (Washington Post/Newswires)

Manhattan DA is said to be considering charges against 2 Trump Organization officials. (NYT)

content:
Asia equity market trade mixed with the region cautious following the weak lead from Wall St, a lack of progress during US-China trade discussions and ongoing political uncertainty in Australia. As such, ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) are mixed with initial support from earnings releases in Australia later overshadowed by the tumultuous political climate, while Tokyo stocks are underpinned by a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) are the worst performers following the stalemate at US-China trade talks and with the biggest movers amongst Hong Kong’s large caps also dictated by earnings.

In FX markets, price action is relatively quiet overnight as the greenback holds on to recent gains against its major counterparts, which has kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD near the prior day’s lows with the latter testing 1.2800 to the downside. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is higher on broad strength in the greenback, antipodeans are subdued after the stalemate at US-China trade talks and with Australia heading into a leadership showdown, while MXN and CAD also languish after Thursday passed without the announcement of the previously-speculated NAFTA handshake agreement.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with demand subdued amid upside in Tokyo stocks, although downside is also stemmed by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 950bln in 1yr-10yr JGBs and following softer than expected CPI data.
